title: Best road bike pedals 2023
content:
Cyclist
Best road bike pedals 2023

The best clipless pedals mechanically attach your feet to the bike. Clipless pedal systems include a mechanism that attaches a cleat bolted to the base of your shoe to the pedal. This will give you improved support, security and power transfer for greater pedalling efficiency.

Working a bit like ski bindings, you simply step onto the pedal and it’ll automatically lock you into place, while a quick twist of the foot releases your shoe. There’s a knack to learning how to use them but once you’ve learned, you’re unlikely to look back.

With single-sided road systems focussing on achieving maximum stiffness and minimum weight, the downside to this is greater difficulty when walking. By comparison, mountain bike or touring systems are usually double-sided, meaning you can clip into either side of the pedal. Not only does this make them easier to clip into, but the smaller cleats they use are recessed in the sole of your shoe, so walking is significantly easier.

Bearing this in mind, we’ve rounded up examples of our favourite road systems, plus some mountain bike-style alternatives worth considering if you’re riding a gravel bike, commuting or want an easier entry point to riding clipless.

Keep reading for our favourite pedals for all occasions. Or if you want to know more, scroll a bit further for our guide covering everything you always wanted to know about clipping-in.

We’ve quoted system weight for each pedal set. That includes the pedals, cleats and mounting hardware (bolts and any adapters needed). The weight is for a pair.

Why you should trust Cyclist‘s advice

Here at Cyclist, riding and reviewing bikes is our job and we’ve used and abused the whole range of pedal systems, both three-bolt road pedals for road riding and two-bolt pedals for off-road and commuting use.

Website editor Matthew Loveridge, pictured above, is a long-time Wahoo Speedplay and Shimano SPD user, but our highly experienced reviewers regularly swap between pedals and cover the whole gamut of systems, including Shimano, Look and Time.

Although we all have our preferences, no-one uses one pedal system to the exclusion of all others. We know our pedals and what makes a great pedal.

Best road bike pedals 2023 in-depth

Look Keo 2 Max Carbon

£79 (RRP £99) | View offer

  • System weight: 321g
  • Carbon body, Large surface area

Despite sitting in the middle of Look’s hierarchy, its Keo 2 Max Carbon pedals might be its most attractive proposition. You get the low weight you’d hope for, given their carbon construction. However, unlike the top of the line Keo Blades, they still come with adjustable tension.

In practice, this means you can choose how tightly they grip your cleats. This trait is great for beginners, who probably want the release tension low, as well as pros, who’ll like to dial it right up, plus everyone in-between.

They come with a pair of grey Look Keo Grip cleats, which offer a moderate 4.5° float. Again this is likely to suit pretty much everyone, and it’s doubtful you’ll end up locked in the wrong position or that your feet will swing about too much. In fact, our tester referred to them as ‘the baby bear’s porridge of cleats’.

As is the nature of all pedal marketing materials, the latest version of the Keo 2 Max Carbon pedal promises an enlarged usable contact surface to its stainless steel plate. Ensuring a relatively broad platform on which to connect, Look claims its 60mm width offers 25% more surface than before. To be honest, we found it satisfactory before, and can only assume this new version is an improvement.

  • Read our Look Keo 2 Max Carbon pedal review

Shimano Ultegra R8000 pedals

£86.99 (RRP £160) | View offer

  • System weight: 302g
  • Highly durable, 4mm longer axles available

Regardless of not being the lightest, nor sporting the lowest stack height, the Shimano Ultegra pedals do an excellent job, being in our experience the most durable road pedals on the market.

The amount of force required to release your feet is easily controlled via an adjustable spring, while the extra height conceals bearings that will last years between services.

Three different cleats allow you to tune the range of float between 0 and 6°. Once engaged, the available movement feels less slippery than some, which will suit certain riders but not all. The cleats provide ample lateral adjustment. Featuring broad wings tipped with rubber bumpers, they’re also the most stable to walk on.

  • Read our full Shimano Ultegra R8000 pedals review

Shimano Deore XT T8000 pedals

£74.99 (RRP £100) | View offer

  • System weight: 450g
  • Dual sided flat/SPD, Durable

If you’re looking for a pedal that you can ride either clipped in or with flat-soled shoes, the Deore XT T8000 does that. One side has an SPD cleat embedded in it and the other has pins to grip your shoes’ soles.

We liked that the pedal provides a stable base for pedalling whether clipped in or not, without being over-large and that the pedal sits SPD side up for easy engagement. The Deore XT pedals are durable and cope well with the rigours of commuting, when consistent performance trumps low weight or flashy features.

  • Read our full Shimano Deore XT T8000 pedal review

Shimano 105 pedals

£73 (RRP £125) | View offer

  • System weight: 330g
  • Carbon body, Excellent reliability

The Shimano 105 pedals have much of the tech trickled down from Shimano’s higher spec Ultegra and Dura-Ace pedals, including their carbon bodies, hollow axles, spring-adjustable release tension and a similar pedal geometry, although with a slightly higher stack height. They share the three cleat float options of Shimano’s other pedals too.

They’re highly durable and easy to service, so you can expect long pedal life. You can usually find them at prices substantially below their list price, making them something of a bargain too.

  • Read our full Shimano 105 PD-R7000 pedal review

Wahoo Speedplay Zero pedals

£199.99 | View offer

  • System weight: 384g
  • Highly adjustable, Multiple axle lengths available, Pro looks

A double-sided pedal, Wahoo Speedplay’s brilliant design turns pedal technology on its head by placing the spring in the cleat rather than the pedal.

This opens up several possibilities, probably the most important of which is that the amount of float and the release angle can now be up to 15 degrees – or it can be reduced to zero in either direction, with stepless adjustability. It’s a quality that makes them ideal for those whose foot moves laterally through the pedal stroke or who find the lower adjustability of other systems uncomfortable.

Speedplay’s design also brings the two components really close together for a low stack height, which improves pedalling dynamics, all thanks to the four-bolt cleat (through a three-bolt converter is available to make them compatible with a wider choice of shoes). They also look splendidly minimalist on the bike – which never hurts.

The Wahoo Speedplay Zero pedals, although not the other Speedplay pedals, also offer four axle lengths, which adds even more fine-tuning of your stance width. Still a little trickier to learn how to use than other brands, Wahoo Speedplay’s benefits nevertheless continue to win its pedals legions of devotees.

This hardwearing stainless version is one of the more cost-efficient, with Wahoo Speedplay’s prices going up to the £380 titanium Nano with plenty of stops in between. Known as Wahoo Powrlink, single and double-sided power meter versions are also available.

  • Read our full Wahoo Speedplay Zero pedal review

Look Keo Blade Carbon Ceramic pedals

£144.99 (RRP £190) | View offer

  • System weight: 330g
  • Lightweight, Streamlined profile

Most clipless pedals these days still resemble the original model invented in 1984 by French brand, Look. But Look’s high-end pedals replace the metal coil spring with a carbon leaf spring. This limits adjustability, as there are just three spring options with preset release tensions, but it does lead to a streamlined look to the pedals and, along with the carbon body, lowers weight.

Add in the ceramic bearings and you’ve got a lightweight, smooth pedal, while you can add titanium axles to lose even more weight if you have money to burn or an obliging sponsor.

Look cleats are resilient little buggers at the best of times with float options spanning 0-6°.

  • Read our full Look Keo Blade Carbon Ceramic pedal review

Shimano Dura-Ace PD-R9100 pedals

£144.99 (RRP. £235) | View offer

  • System weight: 306g
  • Low stack height, Very light engagement action

Shimano’s top spec pedals include a range of quality features. Their outboard bearings on the crank end of the spindle increase the distance between the two bearing sets and decrease stack height, they come with Shimano’s lower float blue cleats and even the cleat bolts are hollow to save 2g a set. They’re light, although not as light as some competitors at their price.

Although the list price may look elevated, the Dura-Ace pedals can be had for a lot less cash. They arguably justify their cost, with a super-light engagement action and a feel that is more precise than Shimano’s lower spec pedals and many of their competitors in the premium pedal market.

  • Read our full Shimano Dura-Ace PD-R9100 pedal review

Shimano PD-M520 pedals

£28.99 (RRP £35) | View offer

  • System weight: 390g
  • Dual-sided entry, Rugged, Low price

Two bolt systems are a good option for gravel biking, commuting and winter road riding, as they are simpler to clip into, have much more grip and make walking less of a chore.

The entry level of Shimano’s off-road focussed SPD pedal range, the M520 is a low priced option, but is very rugged. The dual-sided entry makes engagement very easy and the open body sheds debris well. It’s a little heavier and has a higher stack height than three-bolt road pedal systems but has excellent durability.

The skeletal design relies on the shoe’s sole and lugs for foot stability. If your shoes and cleats are in good shape, engagement between feet and pedals is firm, allowing for efficient pedalling, but with wear it can become a little slack.

  • Read our full Shimano PD-M520 SPD pedal review

Wahoo Speedplay Comp pedals

£134.99 | View offer

  • System weight: 386g
  • Easier engagement than other Speedplay pedals, Same high adjustability

The Wahoo Speedplay Comp pedals are the entry level model of the Speedplay pedal range and offer a lower engagement force than the higher spec models, making for a shallower learning curve. They retain the same high adjustability of all Speedplay pedals though, with independent inward and outward float and engagement angles.

They also have the same low stack height, although unless you have cycling shoes with four-bolt connections, you’ll need to fit the plastic three-bolt adapter below the cleat which increases stack height somewhat. It’s still lower than Wahoo Speedplay’s competitors though.

  • Read our full Wahoo Speedplay Comp pedal review

Look Keo 3 Classic Plus pedals

£44.99 (RRP £62) | View offer

  • System weight: 342g
  • Entry level Look pedal with the same tech as the Keo 2 Max, standard release tension

The Look Keo 3 Classic Plus pedals provide a low priced entry into Look’s road pedal system, but whereas the Shimano RS500 pedals have an easier release tension than Shimano’s other pedals, the Look pedals have a similar release to the higher spec Keo pedals. As with the Keo 2 Max Carbon, the tension can be adjusted via the release spring at the rear of the pedal body. The Plus denotes the design with steel wear plates sunk into the top surface of the pedal; there’s also a Keo 3 Classic without these.

Instead of carbon, the pedal bodies are fibreglass composite, which increases the weight somewhat. The stack height is comparable to Look’s other steel spring designs and is a little higher than competing pedal systems. None of that is to the detriment of ride quality, although you need to be careful to keep the spindles dry after use to avoid rusting in wet weather.

  • Read our full Look Keo 3 Classic Plus pedal review

Time Xpresso 7 pedals

£83.99 (RRP £113) | View offer

  • System weight: 296g
  • Cleat remains open for easy engagement, Lateral float in the cleat, Lightweight

Time’s pedals have a rear retainer which stays open when your shoe isn’t in place, making for very easy engagement. Once clipped in, there’s plenty of float, as the cleat can move laterally as well as twist in the pedal, although this can make things seem a little imprecise.

The Xpresso 7 has a carbon body and is one of the lightest pedals available despite its place at the top of Time’s entry-level Xpresso range. It has a spare, cut-down look too.

As with the Look Keo Blade, it uses a carbon leaf spring, which limits adjustability of the release tension, but makes for a neater look. Be careful of the sharp edges both at the front and rear of the pedal though, which can give you a sharp knock.

  • Read our full Time Xpresso 7 pedal review

Time Xpro 10 pedals

£120.80 (RRP £151) | View offer

  • System weight: 320g
  • Streamlined design, Wide engagement surface, Time’s open cleat tech

The Time Xpro 10 is actually a little heavier than the Xpresso 7, thanks to the enclosed base, beefed up retainers and slightly larger surface area. It shares much of the Xpresso’s tech though including the carbon leaf spring closure and the cleat which remains open until you clip in.

The Xpro 10 is the bottom of the Xpro range, with two pedal options above it, including the very light, very spendy Xpro 15, still the lightest pedal available from any brand at a claimed 174g a pair. It’s well made and a good alternative to Look or Shimano. The rear end is smoother than the Xpresso 7 so it’s less likely to give yo a sharp knock, although it still has sharp edges to the front retainer.

  • Read our full Time Xpro 10 pedal review

Shimano RS500 SPD-SL pedals

£39.99 (RRP £60) | View offer

  • Price: £60
  • System weight: 400g
  • Low price, Lighter release tension than other Shimano pedals

Shimano’s entry level RS500 pedals have a lower release tension than its pricier pedals, making them an option for clipless pedal newbies. You can still crank it up once you gain confidence, although the next-up 105 pedals adjust almost as low.

As with all Shimano’s pedals, they’re very durable and require minimal servicing to keep them running smoothly.

There’s the same look as the 105 pedals, although the RS500s have composite plastic rather than carbon bodies. They’re also quite a bit heavier than the Shimano 105 pedals, mainly due to their steel axles being solid rather than hollow. We’d suggest saving up for the 105 pedals, in all honesty, for their lower weight and superior build.

Everything you always wanted to know about clipping in (but were afraid to ask)

Mechanically attaching your feet to a bicycle has many benefits, but how do you choose the best road bike pedals that fix you to yours?

The cleat which attaches to your shoe engages with the pedal. The connection is spring-loaded and releases with a twist of the foot. Rather than fixing your feet rigidly most clipless pedals allow some movement or ‘float’.

The majority of road cycling shoes come with a three-bolt design, as pioneered by Look. Speedplay uses a four-bolt connection between the cleat and the shoe’s sole, whereas two bolts are used on the smaller MTB cleats, which are less cumbersome and the best option if you’ll be doing any significant walking in your cycling shoes.

You’ll find that above a certain price, bikes no longer come with pedals, or come with basic plastic ones. In part, this saves money but since pedals are a such a personal thing, it means you can choose a pair that suit your needs.

Going with the first thing the shop assistant suggests or picking the ones that are half price online might not be the best approach. We’ve rounded up clipless road bike pedals (so-called because they do away with traditional toe-clips) from the leading makers and tried them for ourselves.

We’ve also enlisted the help of pedal expert Spencer Wilson to explain what we should be looking for, along with the pros and cons of each system.

‘No single feature, be it weight, rotational movement, float, or whatever else makes a pedal the “best”,’ says Wilson.

‘At Personal Bikefit, the most important factor for us to understand is how the pedal interacts with the shoe, and therefore the wearer while riding. Does it provide a degree of guidance for your foot so that the union between shoe and pedal is secure? Or, is there a lack of guidance allowing the foot to move too freely?

‘At the same time, you don’t want your foot excessively fixed – a frequent problem that was found with early clipless pedals – as in some cases, this can result in knee injuries.’

Wilson continues: ‘Rider biomechanics are also a crucial factor when it comes to picking a pedal. So, for example, weak glutes can force riders to drive forces across the top of the pedal instead of pushing downward and evenly onto the pedal platform.

‘It’s no good having a large pedal/shoe interface if the forces are not being applied to it evenly. If the loading forces aren’t in line with the pedal spindle, for example, or your knees aren’t able to track in a vertically straight line, then no kind of pedal – no matter how well-made it is – will be able to correct this,’ Wilson adds.

What to look out for

Platform size

The bigger the pedal surface area, or platform, the more robust the relationship between the cleat and the pedal will be. This helps keep the pedal as comfortable during the fifth hour of a ride as it is during the first, while also providing the most efficient power transfer.

Q Factor adjustment

The Q Factor is the distance between the centreline of the pedals, laterally. Not all pelvic widths are the same! To produce maximum power, the knee needs to track in a vertical line as this is both most efficient and reduces the risk of knee pain.

Look for cleats with good lateral adjustment or, even better, use pedals that are available with different axle lengths – higher spec Shimano pedals offer this, but the Wahoo Speedplay Zero pedals are the Q Factor kings with four different axle lengths available.

Float

A cleat and pedal system with a zero-degree or ‘fixed’ float will lock your feet rigidly in place. However, most riders will prefer to have a little wiggle room. Measured in degrees, float is the amount that your heel can move side-to-side before disengaging from the pedal.

Most manufacturers sell different cleats with different amounts of float, while Speedplay cleats can be carefully adjusted to tailor the degree of rotational freedom available for your foot.

Release tension

A special consideration for riders new to using clipless pedals and who need easy engagement and disengagement. More experienced riders, especially those who like to mash the pedals when sprinting, frequently prefer the security offered by a stiffer release tension.

Many high-end pedals now use a carbon leaf spring instead of the traditional coiled steel spring to provide tension. This saves weight but means that the effort needed to clip out can only be adjusted in fixed increments.

Pedals that possess a good range of spring tension can be adjusted for novice and elite riders alike, while some pedals have easier release for new clipped-in riders or those who prefer a very low release tension.

A good range and adjustment of rotation

Riders with biomechanical imbalances and lower-limb issues may need a more precise setup and require more rotation. Speedplay pedals are the perfect choice for this, allowing 15° of rotation right down to zero. Time pedals also allow a large degree of float.

This not only protects your knees against potential damage but means there’s less chance of you accidentally unclipping. It can feel as if your pedal stroke is a little unguided though.

Reliability

This is a sometimes forgotten factor in pedal choice. In order to slim down their pedals, manufacturers use smaller and smaller bearings and bushes. While these can be replaced fairly cheaply, doing so can be tricky and time-consuming.

For our money, you can’t beat Shimano for durability, although Look has upgraded its bearings too recently.

Stack height

The height from the pedal axle to the sole of the foot. If you choose pedals with a high stack height, you may also need to raise your saddle height in order to compensate. In theory, a lower stack height increases pedalling efficiency, although in practice the effects are slight and you’re unlikely to notice them.
